item.title: Introduction to Species Distribution Modeling using R Language: theory and practice
item.description: The wide availability of data on biodiversity and environmental variables favor the use of spatial analysis, including the Species Distribution Modeling (SDM). In this workshop, I will offer a theoretical and practical introduction to the SDM technique using the R language. First, I will briefly present the main concepts of ecological niche theory (Grinnell, Elton and Hutchinson) and DEM theory (geographical space (G), space environmental (E) and Biotic-Abiotic-Movement diagram (BAM)). Following the theoretical part, I will present the main databases (occurrences and environmental variables), types of algorithms (BIOCLIM, Mahalanobis, Gower, GLM, GAM, Random Forest, SVM and MaxEnt), evaluation of models (ROC, AUC and TSS) , cut-off limits (thresholds) and model consensus (ensembles). The practical part will focus on the construction of models using the R language, where I will address: (1) introduction to the R language, (2) obtaining and selecting data on occurrences and environmental variables, (3) adjusting and predicting the models, (4) evaluation metrics, (5) model consensus (ensembles) and (6) map composition.

item.title: Cartography Applications for Spatial Ecology
item.description: Cartography has several applications in other areas of knowledge that need to perform the visualization of geospatial data. In this lecture I demonstrate some applications of cartography for Spatial Ecology, mainly in relation to Species Distribution Models.

item.title: Species Distribution Models: an overview
item.description: Species Distribution Models (SDMs) relate species occurrence data with their environmental conditions to estimate the species’ niche and thus predict new areas of possible distribution. In this lecture, I spoke of the main concepts, input data and applications of this approach in the area of Ecology.
